ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Take it if you like to paint and are self-directed. If you're expecting an intense experience, then wait for Robert Reed's painting course.
I thought we'd learn a lot more than we did and do a lot more paintings, but it was an okay class.
Yes. Don't be afraid if you're not an art major. It is a great relaxing hands-on and creative experience.

Introduction to oil painting. Do a few color/technique studies, then a few bigger projects. Assignments are pretty open ended. I would recommend it if you really like or are studying painting. It definitely helps to have drawing/painting experience. Probably just for art majors, unless you're willing to put in the time and energy.

4 to 5 assignments with group crits following each. Requires a lot of time, so keep that in mind when making your schedule. It's great if you already have ideas about what you want to do but it can be a little frustrating if you go in with the expectation that there would be a lot of direction. Painting with oil is lots of fun though!
I recommend this class to those who are serious about art.

A good class but could be more rigorous. I felt like the projects were fun but the speed of the class could have been much faster. One painting a week would have been ideal. A mandatory sketchbook would have been even better to develop visual concepts outside of class.
